questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to an ophthalmologist with occasional headaches and no specific vision complaints. The examination reveals increased cupping of the optic disc, visual field defects, and elevated intraocular pressure. A diagnosis of primary open-angle glaucoma is made. Treatment is initiated with topical eye drops and regular follow-up visits are scheduled. The following finding is noticed on a follow-up visit. Which drug(s) is/are responsible for it?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient reported with complaints of blurring of vision in his left eye for the past 2 weeks. He had a past history of central retinal vein occlusion in the left eye, which was diagnosed almost 3 months back. Slit lamp examination revealed rubeosis iridis in all the four quadrants. The intraocular pressure (IOP) in left eye is 72 mm of Hg. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neovascular Glaucoma (NVG)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Primary Angle Closure Glaucoma is caused by the physical closure of the anterior chamber angle , leading to increased IOP . It does not typically involve rubeosis iridis.
  • • Option A. Primary Angle Closure Glaucoma
  • • physical closure
  • • anterior chamber angle
  • • increased IOP
  • • Option C. Posner-Schlossman Syndrome, also known as Glaucomatocyclitic Crisis , this condition typically presents with mild elevation of IOP and not with rubeosis iridis. It's characterized by recurrent attacks of mild inflammation and elevated IOP .
  • • Option C. Posner-Schlossman Syndrome,
  • • Glaucomatocyclitic Crisis
  • • mild elevation
  • • IOP
  • • recurrent attacks
  • • mild inflammation
  • • elevated IOP
  • • Option D. Iridocorneal Endothelial Syndrome rare condition affects the cornea and iris and can lead to secondary glaucoma . It does not typically involve rubeosis iridis.
  • • Option D. Iridocorneal Endothelial Syndrome
  • • affects
  • • cornea
  • • iris
  • • secondary glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Considering the presence of rubeosis iridis in all four quadrants and the significantly elevated IOP , the diagnosis is Neovascular Glaucoma . This condition is often a consequence of ischemic retinal diseases and presents with new blood vessel formation on the iris and angle , leading to increased intraocular pressure due to impaired aqueous humor drainage .

  • ➤ rubeosis iridis

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of painless, gradually progressive reduction of vision of the right eye over several months. IOP was OD: 55mmHg and OS: 19mmHg. Anterior chamber was of normal depth in both eyes. A white flaky disc was seen on the anterior lens capsule after dilatation in both eyes. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Uveitis Glaucoma is secondary to uveitis . Signs of active inflammation , such as cells and flare in the anterior chamber or synechiae ( adhesion of the iris to the lens or cornea ), might be expected .

  • • Option C. Pigmentary glaucoma is caused by the dispersion of pigment granules from the iris into aqueous humor . This pigment can clog the trabecular meshwork , increasing intraocular pressure . Typical signs include mid-peripheral iris transillumination defects , dense pigmentation of the trabecular meshwork , and a Krukenberg spindle (a vertical deposition of pigment on the corneal endothelium ).

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of Applanation Tonometer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Schiotz Tonometer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Goldmann tonometer : This is the most widely used type of applanation tonometer . It measures IOP by flattening a small , known area of the cornea. The force required to flatten this area correlates with the IOP . It's considered the gold standard for IOP measurement .
  • • Option B. Goldmann tonometer
  • • applanation tonometer
  • • IOP
  • • flattening a small
  • • area

  • • IOP
  • • gold standard
  • • IOP measurement
  • • Option C. Perkins tonometer is a portable version of the Goldmann tonometer , using the same principle of applanation. It's particularly useful for bedridden patients or those who cannot sit at a slit lamp where a Goldmann tonometer is typically used.
  • • Option C. Perkins tonometer
  • • portable version
  • • Goldmann tonometer
  • • bedridden patients
  • • cannot sit
  • • slit lamp
  • • Goldmann tonometer
  • • Option D. Tonopen involves both applanation and indentation processes . It is a small, handheld , battery-powered portable device . The tonometer has an applanating footplate with a tiny plunger protruding minimally from the center . As the tonometer makes contact with the eye , the plunger receives resistance from the cornea and the IOP producing a record of rising force by a strain gauge . At the moment of applanation , the force is shared by the foot plate and the plunger resulting in a momentary small decrease from the steadily increasing force . This is the point of applanation which is recorded electronically . Multiple readings are averaged. Because the area of applanation is known, the IOP can then be calculated. The readings correlate well with Goldmann tonometry within normal IOP ranges.
  • • Option D. Tonopen

  • • Option C. Phacomorphic Glaucoma
  • • swollen cataractous lens
  • • angle closure
  • • elevated IOP

  • • elevated IOP

questions.text: A 55-year-old asthmatic male presents to an ophthalmology clinic with complaints of gradual vision loss and occasional headaches. Examination reveals optic nerve damage and visual field defects consistent with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). Intraocular pressure is elevated, and the patient's cup-to-disc ratio is increased. The first line management for POAG is medical, by drugs that lower intraocular pressure. All of the following can be prescribed to him, except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Timolol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

  • • generally safe
  • • asthmatic patients

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the biochemical composition of aqueous humour:

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: The Protein Concentration is less than that of Blood Plasma

questions.correct_answer: D. The Protein Concentration is less than that of Blood Plasma
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) The Protein Concentration is less than that of Blood Plasma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Albumin – globulin ratio is reversed : Normal aqueous humour and the aqueous humour of patients with cataract is virtually protein-free . Patients having retinoblastoma and non-malignant post-inflammatory lesions show significantly high quantities of proteins in the aqueous humour . Retinoblastoma is associated with an increase in the globulin content and an albumin/globulin ratio below unity , while non-malignant post-inflammatory intraocular conditions show a rise of the albumin fraction with an albumin/globulin ratio above unity .
  • • Option A.

  • • unity
  • • Option B. Water constitutes only 20% of aqueous humour : This statement is incorrect. The aqueous humor is predominantly made up of water , constituting more than 90% of its composition . The rest is made up of salts , proteins , and other substances in very small quantities .

  • • Option C. Prostaglandins are absent : Prostaglandins can be present in the aqueous humor , though usually in very low concentrations . They play a role in various physiological and pathological processes in the eye , including the regulation of intraocular pressure and inflammation .
  • • Option C.

questions.text: SWAP-Short Wavelength Automated Perimetry (SWAP), can detect early visual field loss in glaucoma using which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Blue on Yellow Perimetry

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B . Red on green: This is not the method used in SWAP. Red on green perimetry is not specifically designed for early glaucoma detection and does not target the blue-sensitive photoreceptors.
  • • Option B
  • • Option C . Black on white: This describes standard achromatic perimetry , which is the conventional method used in many visual field tests. While useful for detecting glaucomatous damage , it is not as sensitive as SWAP in the early stages of the disease.
  • • Option C
  • • standard achromatic perimetry
  • • conventional method
  • • detecting glaucomatous damage
  • • Option D . White on white: Like black on white, this is another form of standard achromatic perimetry . It's commonly used in routine visual field testing but does not have the same early detection capability for glaucoma as SWAP.
  • • Option D
  • • standard achromatic perimetry
  • • routine visual field testing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Short Wavelength Automated Perimetry (SWAP) detects early glaucomatous damage by using a blue stimulus on a yellow background . This method targets the blue-sensitive photoreceptors , which are more vulnerable to early glaucomatous damage .
  • ➤ early glaucomatous damage
  • ➤ blue stimulus

  • ➤ targets

  • ➤ more vulnerable

questions.text: A 55-year-old hypermetropic patient with a shallow anterior chamber came for an ophthalmic consultation. Post administration of a drug in the right eye, the patient developed pain and redness in the right eye associated with headache. The drug inducing this would be?

Ans. B) Tropicamide

Steroids like rimexolone can increase intraocular pressure , particularly in individuals predisposed to open-angle glaucoma , but they are not typically associated with causing angle-closure glaucoma.

  • • Option C.
  • • miotic

questions.text: In a patient using Pilocarpine eye drops, which side effect is not expected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Iris Pigmentation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Miosis, or constriction of the pupil, is a direct effect of pilocarpine . By stimulating muscarinic receptors in the iris sphincter muscle , pilocarpine causes the pupils to constrict . This is an expected side effect .

  • • pupils

  • • expected side effect
  • • Option C . Brow ache or headache is a common side effect of pilocarpine . This occurs due to the contraction of the ciliary muscle and the muscles of the iris , which can cause discomfort around the eyes and forehead .
  • • Option C
  • • common side effect
  • • pilocarpine
  • • contraction
  • • ciliary muscle
  • • muscles
  • • iris
  • • discomfort
  • • eyes
  • • forehead
  • • Option D . Pilocarpine can cause accommodative spasm , which is an involuntary contraction of the ciliary muscle leading to excessive focusing ability of the eye for near vision . This can result in blurred vision for distance and eye strain .
  • • Option D
  • • accommodative spasm
  • • involuntary contraction
  • • ciliary muscle
  • • excessive focusing ability
  • • eye
  • • near vision
  • • blurred vision
  • • distance
  • • eye strain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ While pilocarpine, a cholinergic agonist , commonly causes miosis , brow ache , and accommodative spasm as side effects due to its mechanism of action , it does not cause increased iris pigmentation, which is more typical of prostaglandin analogues .

questions.text: A patient underwent prophylactic Nd:YAG peripheral iridotomy. All of the following agents is prescribed to counter post procedure spike in IOP, except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pilocarpine

Explanation:

  • • Option B . Dorzolamide, topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor reduces IOP by decreasing aqueous humor production . It is also used in glaucoma management and can be used post-laser procedures to control IOP spikes .

  • • control IOP spikes
  • • Option C . Apraclonidine, an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that reduces IOP by decreasing aqueous humor production and increasing uveoscleral outflow . It is specifically used to prevent or treat spikes in IOP after laser eye surgery , making it highly relevant in this context.
  • • Option C
  • • alpha-2 adrenergic agonist
  • • reduces IOP
  • • decreasing aqueous humor production
  • • increasing uveoscleral outflow
  • • prevent
  • • treat spikes
  • • laser eye surgery
  • • highly relevant

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pilocarpine is the exception , as it is less likely to be prescribed post Nd:YAG peripheral iridotomy to counter a spike in IOP , given that the procedure itself addresses the issue pilocarpine is used to manage.
